First Commercial Flight of the DC-3
In the early 1930's, American Airlines approached the
The full-color cachet shows an American Airlines
Douglas Aircraft Company to design a sleeper aircraft
DC-3 making the first non-stop run between New
for the U.S. transcontinental route. The three re-
York and Chicago. By 1946, when the last DC-3's were
quirements were that the plane be fast, safe and

for civil and military use of the aircraft had been built

The new plane could accommodate 21 passengers on

On June 25, 1936, American Airlines began DC-3
operations with daytime service between New York
Mint Stamp: The mint stamp on this Cover, showing a
DC-3 in flight, was issued by Berlin in 1979. The initial
American Airlines order was for 20 DC-3's, with an
option for 20 more at a price of $110,000 each.
and Chicago. Overnight transcontinental service fol-
lowed three months later. By the end of the 1930's,
DC-3's accounted for about 90% of the world's air-
line trade.
Postmark: This Cover was postmarked in Chicago,
Illinois on June 25, 1984, the exact anniversary of the
first commercial flight of the Douglas DC-3.

properties.sfomuseum:description: Airmail flight cover, part of International Tributes to the History of Flight series by the Postal Commemorative Society; white envelope with full color illustration cachet and inset stamp commemorating first/inaugural commercial flight of the DC-3 on June 25, 1936, in Chicago, Illinois, U.S.A., by American Airlines with Douglas DC-3; cancellation stamp dated June 25, 1984 in Chicago; includes information on reverse.
